title: More than 2m Brits to head overseas this weekend
text:
More than 2m Brits to head overseas this weekend 23 July 2015 Save 
A total of 2.1 million British holidaymakers are set to travel overseas this weekend in the wake of the majority of English and Welsh schools breaking up. 
The key beneficiary of the mass migration will be Spain, where the Canary and Balearic island remain popular, as well as Cyprus, France and Greece as Brits take advantage of an eight-year high of the pound against the euro. 
In the long-haul market both the Dominican Republic and Mexico have sold well but not enough to knock Florida off the top spot. 
The rush abroad will mean airports face a busy weekend with450,000 passengers departing from Heathrow, 310,000 from Gatwick, 160,000 from Stansted and 90,000 from Luton. 
A further 171,000 are due to depart from Manchester, 73,000 from Birmingham and 50,000 from Bristol. 
Meanwhile, more than 100,000 will be leaving from Scottish airports with half going via Glasgow, while 71,000 will use the Eurostar. 
ABTA chief executive Mark Tanzer said: “This weekend sees the great summer getaway in full swing with all of the schools in the UK having broken up for their summer break and hundreds of thousands of UK holidaymakers heading off for a break. 
“Destinations around the Mediterranean remain the firm favourites for British families with Spain and Greece leading the way. 
“Many ABTA members are reporting an increase in late bookings to Greece following the recent progress in securing a bailout, with customers taking advantage of some exceptional deals. 
“For those flying long haul, Florida and Dubai are very popular this year, with families benefitting from the cut in child air taxes that was introduced in May. 
“Holidaymakers will also see their spending money going further with the pound having increased in value against a wide range of currencies, particularly the Euro, over the last twelve months.” 
Abta added its fifth annual Abta MP Holiday Survey has revealed 77% of the 150 MPs surveyed will be taking an overseas holiday, up from 69% the previous year. 
The survey revealed 82% of Conservative MPs will travel abroad compared with 73% of Labour and SNP MPs. 
The association added many will also ape prime minister David Cameron by combining a domestic break, he is taking two, as well as a trip overseas. 
However, 15% added they don’t always take out travel insurance when going abroad, believing an Ehic card and using their credit cards to make any bookings will leave them adequately covered. 
Stephen D’Alfonso, ABTA head of public affairs, said: “This year’s survey results show that an overseas summer holiday is as important to MPs as it is to the great British public. 
“As Parliament heads into recess after months of campaigning around the general election, followed by a busy start to the parliamentary session, it is notable just how many MPs are eager to get a little rest and respite abroad. 
“Those MPs heading abroad will know all too well about the negative impact of Air Passenger Duty – a levy charged on all passengers flying out of the UK – on their holiday budgets. 
“MPs with children under the age of 12 will certainly benefit from recent changes by the Treasury to abolish APD on children’s flights, but we’re calling on the government to go further to reduce APD for hard-pressed families wanting to enjoy their well-earned overseas break.”
